qas.question: When did Western governments support fledgling Islamists?
What did some of the Islamist groups supported by the West later become to be seen as?
Western governments considered Islamists to be the lesser of two evils when compared to whom?
Who did the US provide aid to, to fight against the Soviet Union?
What did the non-Afghan veterans returning home have in addition to their prestige?
When did Eastern governments support fledgling Islamists?
What did some of the Islamist groups supported by the East later become to be seen as?
Western governments considered Islamists to be the worse of two evils when compared to whom?
Who did the US refuse aid to, to fight against the Soviet Union?
What did the non-Afghan veterans returning home not have in addition to their prestige?

context: During the 1970s and sometimes later, Western and pro-Western governments often supported sometimes fledgling Islamists and Islamist groups that later came to be seen as dangerous enemies. Islamists were considered by Western governments bulwarks against—what were thought to be at the time—more dangerous leftist/communist/nationalist insurgents/opposition, which Islamists were correctly seen as opposing. The US spent billions of dollars to aid the mujahideen Muslim Afghanistan enemies of the Soviet Union, and non-Afghan veterans of the war returned home with their prestige, "experience, ideology, and weapons", and had considerable impact.
